title: Manila Light Rail Transit System
text:
The Manila Light Rail Transit System (), commonly known as the LRT, is an <a href="urban%20rail%20transit">urban rail transit</a> system that primarily serves <a href="Metro%20Manila">Metro Manila</a>, Philippines. Although categorized as a <a href="light%20rail">light rail</a> system because it originally used light rail vehicles, it presently has characteristics of a <a href="rapid%20transit">rapid transit</a> system, such as high passenger throughput, exclusive right-of-way, and later use of full metro rolling stock. The LRT is jointly-operated by the <a href="Light%20Rail%20Transit%20Authority">Light Rail Transit Authority</a> (LRTA), a government corporation attached to the <a href="Department%20of%20Transportation%20%28Philippines%29">Department of Transportation</a> (DOTr), and the <a href="Light%20Rail%20Manila%20Corporation">Light Rail Manila Corporation</a> (LRMC). Along with the <a href="Manila%20Metro%20Rail%20Transit%20System">Manila Metro Rail Transit System</a> and the <a href="PNR%20Metro%20Commuter%20Line">Metro Commuter Line</a> of the <a href="Philippine%20National%20Railways">Philippine National Railways</a>, the system makes up Metro Manila's rail infrastructure.
The LRT's is mostly elevated and consists of two lines and 33 stations. <a href="LRT%20Line%201%20%28Metro%20Manila%29">Line 1</a>, also called the Green Line (formerly known as the Yellow Line), opened in 1984 and travels a north–south route. <a href="LRT%20Line%202%20%28Metro%20Manila%29">Line 2</a>, the Blue Line (formerly, the Purple Line), was completed in 2004 and runs east–west. The original Line 1 was built as a no-frills means of public transport and lacks some features and comforts, but the newer Line 2 has been built with additional standards and criteria in mind like <a href="barrier-free">barrier-free</a> access. Line 1 serves 500,000 passengers daily while the Line 2 serves 200,000 passengers. Security guards at each station conduct inspections and provide assistance. A reusable plastic magnetic ticketing system has replaced the previous token-based system in 2001, and the Flash Pass was introduced as a step towards a more integrated transportation system. In 2015, the plastic magnetic tickets were replaced with the <a href="Beep%20%28smart%20card%29">Beep</a>, a contactless smart card, introduced to provide a common ticketing to 3 rail lines and some bus lines.
Many passengers who ride the system also take various forms of road-based public transport, such as <a href="bus">bus</a>es and <a href="jeepney">jeepney</a>s, to and from a station to reach their intended destination. Although it aims to reduce <a href="traffic%20congestion">traffic congestion</a> and travel times in the metropolis, the transportation system has only been partially successful due to the rising number of motor vehicles and rapid <a href="urbanization">urbanization</a>. The network's expansion is set on tackling this problem.
Network.
The network consists of two lines: the original Line 1 or Green Line, and the more modern Line 2, or Blue Line. Line 1 is aligned in a general north–south direction along over of fully elevated track. From <a href="Monumento%20station">Monumento</a> it runs south above the hustle and bustle of <a href="Rizal%20Avenue">Rizal</a> and <a href="Taft%20Avenue">Taft Avenue</a>s along <a href="Grade%20separation">grade-separated</a> concrete viaducts allowing exclusive <a href="Right-of-way%20%28transportation%29">right-of-way</a> before ending in <a href="Baclaran%20station">Baclaran</a>. A four-station east–west extension along <a href="Epifanio%20de%20los%20Santos%20Avenue">Epifanio de los Santos Avenue</a> that will connect Monumento to the <a href="North%20Avenue%20Grand%20Central%20station">North Avenue station</a> was opened in 2010, although the common station is not yet constructed. Including the extension's two recently opened stations, <a href="Balintawak%20station">Balintawak</a> and <a href="Roosevelt%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Roosevelt</a>, Line 1 has twenty stations. Line 2 consists of thirteen stations in a general east–west direction over of mostly elevated track, with one station lying underground. Commencing in <a href="Recto%20station">Recto</a>, the line follows a corridor defined by Claro M. Recto and Legarda Avenues, Ramon Magsaysay and <a href="Aurora%20Boulevard">Aurora Boulevard</a>, and the <a href="Marikina-Infanta%20Highway">Marikina-Infanta Highway</a> before reaching the other end of the line at <a href="Antipolo%20station">Antipolo</a>. The system passes through the cities of <a href="Caloocan">Caloocan</a>, <a href="Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="Marikina">Marikina</a>, <a href="Pasay">Pasay</a>, <a href="Pasig">Pasig</a>, <a href="Quezon%20City">Quezon City</a>, and <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Metro%20Manila">San Juan</a>.
During peak hours, Line 1 fields 30 trains at most; the time interval between the departure of one and the arrival of another, called "<a href="headway">headway</a>", is a minimum of 3–4 minutes. On January 9, 2009, Line 1 fielded 31 trains with a headway of 2 minutes to service devotees in celebration of the <a href="Feast%20of%20the%20Black%20Nazarene">Feast of the Black Nazarene</a>. Line 2 on the other hand, runs 10 trains at most with a minimum headway of 5 minutes. With the proper upgrades, the Yellow Line is designed to potentially run with headway as low as 1.5 minutes. Line 2 can run with headway as low as 2 minutes with throughput of up to 60,000 passengers per hour per direction (pphpd).
In conjunction with the <a href="MRT%20Line%203%20%28Metro%20Manila%29">Line 3</a>—also known as the new Yellow Line, a similar but separate metro rail system operated by the private <a href="Metro%20Rail%20Transit%20Corporation">Metro Rail Transit Corporation</a> (MRTC)—the system provides the platform for the vast majority of rail travel in the Metro Manila area. Together with the PNR, the three constitute the SRTS. Recto and <a href="Doroteo%20Jose%20station">Doroteo Jose</a> serve as the sole interchange between both lines of the LRTA. <a href="Araneta%20Center-Cubao%20station%20%28Line%202%29">Araneta Center-Cubao</a> and <a href="EDSA%20station%20%28Line%201%29">EDSA</a> stations serve as interchanges between the LRTA and the MRTC networks. To transfer lines, passengers will need to exit from the station they are in then pass through covered walkways connecting the stations. <a href="Blumentritt%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Blumentritt station</a> meanwhile is immediately above its <a href="Blumentritt%20railway%20station">PNR counterpart</a>.
Baclaran, <a href="Central%20Terminal%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Central Terminal</a>, and Monumento are Line 1's three terminal stations; Recto, Araneta Center-Cubao, and Antipolo are the terminal stations on Line 2. All of them are located on or near major transport routes where passengers can take other forms of transportation such as privately run buses and <a href="jeepney">jeepney</a>s to reach their ultimate destination both within Metro Manila and in neighboring provinces. The system has two depots: Line 1 uses the Pasay Depot at LRTA headquarters in Pasay, near Baclaran station, while the Line 2 uses the Santolan Depot built by <a href="Sumitomo%20Corporation">Sumitomo</a> in Pasig.
Both lines are open every day of the year from 4:30 am <a href="Philippine%20Standard%20Time">PST</a> (<a href="Coordinated%20Universal%20Time">UTC</a>+8) until 10:15 pm on weekdays, and from 5:00 am until 9:50 pm on weekends, except when changes have been announced. During <a href="Holy%20Week">Holy Week</a>, a <a href="Public%20holidays%20in%20the%20Philippines">public holiday in the Philippines</a>, the rail system is closed for annual maintenance, owing to fewer commuters and traffic around the metro. Normal operation resumes on Monday. During the <a href="Christmas">Christmas</a> and year-end holidays, the operating hours of the line are modified and shortened, due to the low ridership of the system during the holidays. Notice of special schedules is given through press releases, via the <a href="public%20address%20system">public address system</a> in every station, and on the LRTA website.
History.
Early train system (1878–1945).
The system's roots date back to 1878 when an official from Spain's Department of Public Works for the Philippines submitted a proposal for a Manila streetcar system. The system proposed was a five-line network emanating from Plaza San Gabriel in <a href="Binondo%2C%20Manila">Binondo</a>, running to <a href="Intramuros">Intramuros</a>, <a href="Malate%2C%20Manila">Malate</a>, <a href="Malaca%C3%B1an%20Palace">Malacañan Palace</a>, <a href="Sampaloc%2C%20Manila">Sampaloc</a> and <a href="Tondo%2C%20Manila">Tondo</a>. The project was approved and in 1882, Spanish-German businessman <a href="Z%C3%B3bel%20de%20Ayala%20family">Jacobo Zóbel de Zangroniz</a>, Spanish engineer <a href="Luciano%20M.%20Bremon">Luciano M. Bremon</a>, and Spanish banker <a href="Adolfo%20Bayo">Adolfo Bayo</a>, founded the "Compañia de los Tranvias de Filipinas" to operate the concession granted by the Spanish colonial government. The Malacañan Palace line was later replaced with a line linking Manila to <a href="Malabon">Malabon</a>, and construction began in 1885. Four German-made steam-operated locomotives and eight coaches for nine passengers each, composed the initial assets of the company. The Manila-Malabon line was the first line of the new system to be finished, opening to the public on October 20, 1888, with the rest of the network opening in 1889. From the beginning it proved to be a very popular line, with services originating from Tondo as early as 5:30 a.m. and ending at 7:30 p.m., while trips from Malabon were from 6:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m., every hour on the hour in the mornings, and every half-hour beginning at 1:30 p.m.
With the American takeover of the Philippines, the <a href="Philippine%20Commission">Philippine Commission</a> allowed the <a href="Meralco">Manila Electric Railroad and Light Company</a> (Meralco) to take over the properties of the "Compañia de los Tranvias de Filipinas", with the first of twelve mandated electric <a href="Tranv%C3%ADa%20%28Manila%29">"tranvia"</a> (tram) lines operated by MERALCO opening in Manila in 1905. At the end of the first year around of track had been laid. A five-year reconstruction program was initiated in 1920, and by 1924, 170 cars serviced many parts of the city and its outskirts. Although it was an efficient system for the city's 220,000 inhabitants, by the 1930s the streetcar network had stopped expanding.
Post-war (1945 – 1970s).
The system was closed during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. By the war's end, the <a href="tram">tram</a> network was damaged beyond repair amid a city that lay in ruins. It was dismantled and <a href="jeepney">jeepney</a>s became the city's primary form of transportation, plying the routes once served by the tram lines. With the return of buses and cars to the streets, traffic congestion became a problem.
In 1966, the Philippine government granted a franchise to Philippine Monorail Transport Systems (PMTS) for the operation of an inner-city <a href="monorail">monorail</a>. The monorail's feasibility was still being evaluated when the government asked the <a href="Japan%20International%20Cooperation%20Agency">Japan International Cooperation Agency</a> (JICA) to conduct a separate transport study. Prepared between 1971 and 1973, the JICA study proposed a series of circumferential and radial roads, an inner-city rapid transit system, a commuter railway, and an expressway with three branches. After further examination, many recommendations were adopted; however, none of them involved rapid transit and the monorail was never built. PMTS' franchise subsequently expired in 1974.
Another study was performed between 1976 and 1977, this time by <a href="Hyder%20Consulting">Freeman Fox and Associates</a> and funded by the <a href="World%20Bank">World Bank</a>. It originally suggested a street-level railway, but its recommendations were revised by the newly formed Ministry of Transportation and Communications (now the <a href="Department%20of%20Transportation%20%28Philippines%29">DOTC</a>). The ministry instead called for an elevated system because of the city's many intersections. However, the revisions increased the price of the project from ₱1.5 billion to ₱2 billion. A supplementary study was conducted and completed within three months.
Advent of Line 1 (1970s to 2003).
President <a href="Ferdinand%20Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a> created the <a href="Light%20Rail%20Transit%20Authority">Light Rail Transit Authority</a> (LRTA) on July 12, 1980, by virtue of Executive Order No. 603 giving birth to what was then dubbed the "Metrorail". First Lady <a href="Imelda%20Marcos">Imelda Marcos</a>, then governor of Metro Manila and minister of human settlements, became its first chairman. Although responsible for the operations of the system, the LRTA primarily confined itself to setting and regulating fares, planning extensions and determining rules and policies, leaving the day-to-day operations to a sister company of Meralco called the Meralco Transit Organization (METRO Inc.). Initial assistance for the project came in the form of a ₱300 million <a href="soft%20loan">soft loan</a> from the <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> government, with an additional ₱700 million coming from a consortium of companies comprising <a href="SA%20Ateliers%20de%20Constructions%20Electriques%20de%20Charleroi">SA Ateliers de Constructions Electriques de Charleroi</a> (ACEC) and <a href="La%20Brugeoise%20et%20Nivelles%20SA.">BN Constructions Ferroviaires et Métalliques</a> (today both part of <a href="Bombardier%20Transportation">Bombardier Transportation</a>), <a href="Tractebel">Tractionnel Engineering International</a> (TEI) and Transurb Consult (TC). Although expected to pay for itself from revenues within twenty years of the start of operation, it was initially estimated that the system would lose money until at least 1993. For the first year of operation, despite a projected ₱365 million in gross revenue, losses of ₱216 million were thought likely.
Construction of Line 1 started in September 1981 with the Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines (now the <a href="Philippine%20National%20Construction%20Corporation">Philippine National Construction Corporation</a>) as the contractor with assistance from Losinger & Cie, a Swiss firm (today Losinger Marazzi), and the Philippine subsidiary of the U.S.-based <a href="Dravo%20Corporation">Dravo Corporation</a>. The government appointed Electrowatt Engineering Services of Zürich to oversee construction and eventually became responsible for the extension studies of future expansion projects. The line was test-run in March 1984, and the first half of Line 1, from Baclaran to Central Terminal, was opened on December 1, 1984. The second half, from <a href="Central%20Terminal%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Central Terminal</a> to Monumento, was opened on May 12, 1985. Overcrowding and poor maintenance took its toll a few years after opening. In 1990, the Line 1 fell so far into disrepair due to premature wear and tear that trains headed to Central Terminal station had to slow to a crawl to avoid further damage to the support beams below as cracks reportedly began to appear. The premature aging of Line 1 led to an extensive refurbishing and structural capacity expansion program with a help of Japan's ODA.
For the next few years Line 1 operations ran smoothly. In 2000, however, employees of METRO Inc. went on strike, paralyzing Line 1 operations from July 25 to August 2, 2000. Consequently, the LRTA did not renew its operating contract with METRO Inc. that expired on July 31, 2000, and assumed all operational responsibility. At around 12:15 pm on December 30, 2000, a bomb—later learned to have been planted by Islamic terrorists—went off in the front coach of a Line 1 train pulling into Blumentritt station, killing 11 and injuring over 60 people in the most devastating of a series of attacks that day, now known as the <a href="Rizal%20Day%20bombings">Rizal Day bombings</a>.
The Line 2 project (2003 to present).
With Japan's ODA amounting to 75 billion yen in total, the construction of Line 2 began in the 1990s, and the first section of the line, from Santolan to Araneta Center-Cubao, was opened on April 5, 2003. The second section, from Araneta Center-Cubao to <a href="Legarda%20station">Legarda</a>, was opened exactly a year later, with the entire line being fully operational by October 29, 2004. During that time the Line 1 was modernized. Automated fare collection systems using magnetic stripe plastic tickets were installed; air-conditioned trains added; pedestrian walkways between Lines 1, 2, and <a href="Manila%20Metro%20Rail%20Transit%20System%20Line%203">3</a> were completed. In 2005, the LRTA made a profit of ₱68 million, the first time the agency made a profit since the Line 1 became operational in 1984.
A 2-station, extension of Line 2 eastward from <a href="Marikina">Marikina</a> up to Masinag, <a href="Antipolo">Antipolo</a> in the province of <a href="Rizal">Rizal</a> opened to the public on July 5, 2021.
Line 1 Concession to LRMC (2015 to present).
On September 12, 2015, Light Rail Manila Corporation (LRMC), a joint venture company of <a href="Metro%20Pacific%20Investments%20Corporation">Metro Pacific's</a> Metro Pacific Light Rail Corporation (MPLRC), <a href="Ayala%20Corporation">Ayala Corporation's</a> AC Infrastructure Holdings Corporation (AC Infra), and the Philippine Investment Alliance for Infrastructure's Macquarie Infrastructure Holdings (Philippines) PTE Ltd. (MIHPL), started a 32-year concession for the operation and maintenance of Line 1 and the construction of a ₱65 billion extension project to Bacoor, Cavite.
Infrastructure.
Stations.
With the exception of <a href="Katipunan%20station%20%28Line%202%29">Katipunan</a> (which is underground), the LRTA's <a href="List%20of%20Strong%20Republic%20Transit%20System%20stations">33 stations</a> are elevated. They follow one of two different layouts. Most Line 1 stations are composed of only one level, accessible from the street below by stairway, containing the station's concourse and platform areas separated by <a href="fare%20gate">fare gate</a>s. The boarding platforms measure long and wide. <a href="Baclaran%20station">Baclaran</a>, <a href="Central%20Terminal%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Central Terminal</a>, <a href="Carriedo%20station">Carriedo</a>, <a href="Balintawak%20station">Balintawak</a>, <a href="Roosevelt%20station%20%28Line%201%29">Roosevelt</a> and <a href="North%20Avenue%20Grand%20Central%20station">North Avenue</a> stations on the Line 1, and all Line 2 stations are composed of two levels: a lower concourse level and an upper platform level (reversed in the case of Katipunan). Fare gates separate the concourse level from the stairs and escalators that provide access to the platform level. All stations have <a href="side%20platform">side platform</a>s except for Baclaran, which has one side and one <a href="island%20platform">island platform</a>, and Santolan, which has an island platform and in 2021, LRT Line 2 introduced new stations adding <a href="Marikina%20station">Marikina</a> and <a href="Antipolo%20station">Antipolo</a>.
The concourse area at LRTA stations typically contain a passenger assistance office (PAO), ticket purchasing areas (ticket counters and/or ticket machines), and at least one stall that sells food and drinks. Terminal stations also have a public relations office. Stores and <a href="automated%20teller%20machine">ATM</a>s are usually found at street level outside the station, although there are instances where they can be found within the concourse. Some stations, such as Monumento, <a href="Libertad%20station">Libertad</a> and <a href="Araneta%20Center-Cubao%20station%20%28Line%202%29">Araneta Center-Cubao</a>, are directly connected to <a href="shopping%20mall">shopping mall</a>s. Line 2 stations have two restrooms, but Line 1 restrooms have been the subject of criticism not only because of the provisioning of a single washroom at each station expected to serve all passengers (whether male, female, disabled or otherwise), but also because of the impression that the lavatories are poorly maintained and unsanitary.
Originally, Line 1 was not built with accessibility in mind. This is reflected in the Line 1's lack of <a href="barrier-free">barrier-free</a> facilities such as escalators and elevators. It is also inconvenient in other ways: for one, because of the use of side platforms, passengers wishing to access the other platform for the train bound in the opposite direction at single-level Line 1 stations need to exit the station (and by extension, the system) and pay a new fare. The newer Line 2, unlike its counterpart, is designed to be barrier-free and allows seamless transfer between platforms. Built by a joint venture between <a href="Hanjin">Hanjin</a> and <a href="Itochu">Itochu</a>, Line 2 stations have wheelchair ramps, <a href="braille">braille</a> markings, and pathfinding embossed flooring leading to and from the boarding platforms in addition to escalators and elevators.
In cooperation with the "<a href="Philippine%20Daily%20Inquirer">Philippine Daily Inquirer</a>", copies of the "<a href="Inquirer%20Libre">Inquirer Libre</a>"—a free, <a href="Tabloid%20%28paper%20size%29">tabloid</a>-size, <a href="Tagalog%20language">Tagalog</a> version of the "Inquirer" <a href="broadsheet">broadsheet</a>—are available at selected LRTA stations from 6:00 am until the supply runs out.
Rolling stock.
Four types of <a href="rolling%20stock">rolling stock</a> run on the system, with three types used on Line 1 and another used on Line 2. Line 1 railway cars were made either in <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a> by La Bruggeoise et Nivelle, <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a> by <a href="Hyundai%20Rotem">Hyundai Precision</a> and <a href="Adtranz">Adtranz</a> (La bruggeoise et Nivelle and Adtranz are now part of <a href="Bombardier%20Transportation">Bombardier Transportation</a>), or Japan by <a href="Kinki%20Sharyo">Kinki Sharyo</a> and <a href="Nippon%20Sharyo">Nippon Sharyo</a>. The Line 2, unlike the Line 1, runs heavy rail metro cars made in South Korea by <a href="Hyundai%20Rotem">Hyundai Rotem</a> and provided by the Asia-Europe MRT Consortium led by <a href="Marubeni%20Corporation">Marubeni Corporation</a> that have higher passenger capacity and maximum speed. All four types of rolling stock are powered by electricity supplied through overhead wires.
Of the two LRTA lines, the Line 2 prominently employs <a href="wrap%20advertising">wrap advertising</a> in its rolling stock. The Line 1 have begun using wrap advertising as well initially for their second-generation trains, followed by their third-generation trains.
Line 1.
Line 1 at various stages in its history has used a two-car, three-car, and four-car train. The two-car trains are the original first-generation BN trains (railway cars numbered from 1000). Most were transformed into three-car trains, although a lot of two-car trains remain in service. The four-car trains are the more modern second-generation Hyundai Precision and Adtranz (numbered from 1100) and third-generation Kinki Sharyo / Nippon Sharyo (1200) trains. There are 139 railway cars grouped into 40 trains serving the line: 63 of these are first-generation cars, 28 second-generation, and 48 third-generation. One train car (1037) was severely damaged in the Rizal Day bombings and was subsequently decommissioned. The maximum speed of these cars ranges between .
As part of the second phase of expansion on the Yellow Line, 12 new trains made in Japan by Kinki Sharyo and provided by the Manila Tren Consortium were shipped in the third quarter of 2006 and went into service in the first quarter of 2007. The new air-conditioned trains have boosted the capacity of the line from 27,000 to 40,000 passengers per hour per direction.
Line 2.
Line 2 fleet runs eighteen heavy rail four-car trains with lightweight stainless car bodies and 1,500 volt electric motors. They have a top speed of and usually take around thirty minutes to journey from one end of the line to the other. Each train measures wide and long allowing a capacity of 1,628 passengers: 232 seated and 1,396 standing. Twenty sliding doors per side facilitate quick entry and exit. The line's trains also feature air conditioning, driverless <a href="automatic%20train%20operation">automatic train operation</a> from the Operations Control Center (OCC) in Santolan, low-noise control, enabled electric and <a href="Hydraulic%20brake">hydraulic braking</a>, and closed-circuit television inside the trains. Special open spaces and seats are designated for wheelchair users and elderly passengers, and automatic next station announcements are made for the convenience of passengers, especially for the blind.
Signalling.
The system has used various signalling systems throughout its history. The original signalling system used in the LRT Line 1 was based on fixed block and relay type trackside systems. Trains had an <a href="automatic%20train%20stop">automatic train stop</a> system that activates if the train passes by a red signal or over-speeding. In 2007, as part of a capacity expansion project, the signalling system was replaced with a signalling and train control system based on <a href="automatic%20train%20protection">automatic train protection</a> and automatic train supervision using <a href="Siemens">Siemens</a> technology. As part of the line's south extension, by 2022, the existing signalling system used in Line 1 will be replaced by the Atlas 100 solution of <a href="Alstom">Alstom</a>, which is based on <a href="European%20Train%20Control%20System%23Level%201">ETCS Level 1</a>.
On the other hand, Line 2 uses the <a href="automatic%20train%20control">automatic train control</a> system, which has three subsystems: automatic train protection (ATP), <a href="automatic%20train%20operation">automatic train operation</a> (ATO), and automatic train supervision (ATS). The <a href="Automatic%20train%20operation">ATO</a> subsystem automatically drives the trains, while the opening and closing of doors is controlled by an onboard train attendant.
Safety and security.
The system has always presented itself as a safe system to travel on, and despite some <a href="List%20of%20LRT%20incidents%20and%20accidents">incidents</a> a <a href="World%20Bank">World Bank</a> paper prepared by <a href="Halcrow%20Group%20Limited">Halcrow</a> deemed the running of metro rail transit operations overall as "good". Safety notices in both English and <a href="Tagalog%20language">Tagalog</a> are a common sight at the stations and inside the trains. Security guards with megaphones can be seen at boarding areas asking crowds to move back from the warning tiles at the edge of platforms to avoid falling onto the tracks. In the event of emergencies or unexpected events aboard the train, alerts are used to inform passengers about the current state of the operations. The LRTA uses three alerts: Codes Blue, Yellow, and Red.
Smoking, previously banned only at station platforms and inside trains, has been banned at station concourse areas since June 24, 2008. Hazardous chemicals, such as paint and gasoline, as well as sharp pointed objects that could be used as weapons, are forbidden. Full-sized <a href="bicycle">bicycle</a>s and <a href="skateboard">skateboard</a>s are also not allowed on board the train, although the ban on <a href="folding%20bicycle">folding bicycle</a>s was lifted on November 8, 2009. Those under the influence of alcohol may be denied entry into the stations.
In response to the <a href="Rizal%20Day%20bombings">Rizal Day bombings</a>, a series of attacks on December 30, 2000, that included the bombing of a Line 1 train among other targets, and in the wake of greater awareness of terrorism following the <a href="September%2011%2C%202001%20terrorist%20attacks">September 11 attacks</a>, security has been stepped up on board the system. The <a href="Philippine%20National%20Police">Philippine National Police</a> has a special police force assigned at both lines. and <a href="security%20police">security police</a> provided by private companies are assigned to all stations with each having a designated head guard. <a href="Closed-circuit%20television">Closed-circuit television</a>s have been installed to monitor stations and keep track of suspicious activities. To better prepare for and improve response to any adverse incidents, drills simulating terror attacks and earthquakes have been conducted. It is standard practice for bags to be inspected upon entry into stations by guards equipped with hand-held <a href="metal%20detectors">metal detectors</a>. Those who refuse to submit to such inspection may be denied entry. Since May 1, 2007, the LRTA has enforced a policy against making false <a href="bomb%20threat">bomb threat</a>s, a policy already enforced at airports nationwide. Those who make such threats can face penalties in violation of Presidential Decree No. 1727, as well as face legal action. Posted notices on station walls and inside trains remind passengers to be careful and be wary of criminals who may take advantage of the crowding aboard the trains. To address concerns of inappropriate contact on crowded trains, the first coach of Line 1 and Line 2 trains have been designated for <a href="Persons%20with%20reduced%20mobility">PWDs</a> and <a href="Women-only%20passenger%20car">females only</a>.
Fares.
The Manila Light Rail Transit System is one of the least expensive rapid transit systems in <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, costing significantly less to ride than other systems in the region. Fares are distance-based, ranging from 15 to 30 <a href="Philippine%20peso">Philippine peso</a>s (₱), or about 28 to 55 <a href="United%20States%20dollar">U.S. cents</a> (at US$1 = ₱48.47 as of February 2021), depending on the number of stations traveled to reach the destination. Unlike other transportation systems, in which transfer to another line occurs within a station's paid area, passengers have to exit and then pay a new fare for the line they are entering. This is also the case on the Yellow Line when changing boarding platforms to catch trains going in the opposite direction.
The Line 1 uses two different fare structures: one for single journey cards and another for stored value (Beep) cards. Passengers are charged ₱11 upon entering the paid area. Passengers using single journey cards are charged ₱15 for travelling ; ₱20 for ; or ₱30 for distances more than . Stored value (Beep) cards are also charged depending on the distance traveled in kilometers, but on a more finely graduated basis. Beep card users are charged ₱1 for every kilometer traveled, plus the ₱11 boarding charge. The Line 2 uses the same fare matrix with the Line 1, but passengers are charged ₱25 for travelling a distance more than .
Ticketing.
Before 2001, passengers on Line 1 would purchase a token to enter the station. Subsequent upgrades in the fare collection system eventually transitioned the Yellow Line from a token-based system to a ticket-based system, with full conversion to a ticket-based system achieved on September 9, 2001.
Starting September 2015, the old magnetic tickets were decommissioned and replaced by contactless-based smart card technology. Passengers can enter the system paid areas with either a single journey or stored value <a href="Beep%20%28smart%20card%29">Beep Card</a>. The Beep Card can be used on all LRT and MRT lines. Tickets can be sold from ticket booths manned by station agents or on <a href="ticket%20machine">ticket machine</a>/s.
Beep card.
Beep is a reloadable contactless smart card aimed to be a replacement for the magnetic card-based system in paying rail based rapid transit transportation fares in and around Metro Manila. Beep is also aimed to be used in lieu of cash in some convenience stores and other businesses. The Beep system is implemented and operated by AF Payments Incorporated, which is primarily owned by Ayala Corporation and Metro Pacific Investments Corporation.
Magnetic ticket.
Previously, the system uses two types of tickets: a single journey (one-way) ticket whose cost is dependent on the destination, and a stored value (multiple-use) ticket available for ₱100. Senior citizens and disabled passengers can receive fare discounts as mandated by law. Tickets would normally bear a picture of the incumbent <a href="President%20of%20the%20Philippines">president</a>, though some ticket designs have done away with this practice.
Single journey tickets are only valid on the day of purchase and will be unusable afterward. They expire if not used to exit the same station after 30 minutes from entry or if not used to exit the system after 120 minutes from entry. If the ticket expires, the passenger will be required to buy a new one.
Stored value tickets are usable on both lines although a new fare will be charged when transferring from one line to the other. To reduce ticket queues, the LRTA is promoting the use of stored value tickets. Aside from benefitting from a lower fare structure on the Line 1, stored value ticket users can avail of a scheme called the Last Ride Bonus that grants the use of any residual amount in a stored value ticket less than the usual minimum ₱12 fare, or the appropriate fare for the station of arrival from the station of departure, as a full fare. Stored value tickets are not reloadable and are captured by the fare gate after the last use. They expire six months after the date of first use.
Tickets are used both to enter and exit the paid area of the system. A ticket inserted into a fare gate at the station of origin is processed and then ejected allowing a passenger through the <a href="turnstile">turnstile</a>. The ejected ticket is then retrieved while passing through so that it can be used at the exit turnstile at the destination station to leave the premises. Tickets are captured by the exit turnstiles to be reused by the system if they no longer have any value. If it is a stored value ticket with some value remaining, however, it is once again ejected by the fare gate to be taken by the passenger for future use.
Flash Pass.
To better integrate the LRTA and MRTC networks, a unified ticketing system utilizing contactless <a href="smart%20card">smart card</a>s, similar to the <a href="Octopus%20card">Octopus card</a> in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> and the <a href="EZ-Link">EZ-Link</a> card in <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, was made a goal of the SRTS. In a transitional move towards such a unified ticketing system, the Flash Pass was implemented on April 19, 2004, as a stopgap measure. However, plans for a unified ticketing system using smart cards have languished, leaving the Flash Pass to fill the role for the foreseeable future. Originally sold by both the LRTA and the <a href="Metro%20Rail%20Transit%20Corporation">Metro Rail Transit Corporation</a>, the Blue Line operator, the pass was discontinued with the election of <a href="Benigno%20Aquino%20III">Benigno Aquino III</a> as President of the Philippines in 2010.
The pass consisted of two parts: the Flash Pass card and the Flash Pass coupon. A nontransferable Flash Pass card used for validation had to be acquired before a Flash Pass coupon can be purchased. To obtain a card, a passenger needed to visit a designated station and fill out an application form. Although the card is issued free of charge and contains no expiry date, it is expected to be issued only once. Should it be lost, an affidavit of loss had to be submitted before a replacement can be issued. The Flash Pass coupon, which served as a ticket, was linked to the passenger's Flash Pass card through the card number printed on the coupon. Coupons were sold for ₱250 and were valid for unlimited rides on all three lines of the LRTA and MRTC for one week. The card and coupon were used by showing them to a security guard at an opening along the fare gates, who after checking their validity allowed the holder to pass through.
Expansion.
Plans for expanding the LRTA network have been formulated throughout its history and successive administrations have touted trains as one of the keys to relieving Metro Manila of its long-standing traffic problems. Expansion of the system was one of the main projects mentioned in a ten-point agenda laid out by President <a href="Gloria%20Macapagal%20Arroyo">Gloria Macapagal Arroyo</a> in 2005. 
Extensions.
A south extension of Line 1 is under construction. The envisioned line would have 8 stations over ending in <a href="Bacoor">Bacoor</a> in the province of <a href="Cavite">Cavite</a>. It will be the third line extending outside the Metro Manila area after the opening of the Line 2 east extension in <a href="Antipolo">Antipolo</a>, <a href="Rizal">Rizal</a> and the planned Line 7 that starts in North Avenue, <a href="Quezon%20City">Quezon City</a> and ends in <a href="San%20Jose%20Del%20Monte">San Jose Del Monte</a>, <a href="Bulacan">Bulacan</a>. An unsolicited bid to build and operate this project from Canada's <a href="SNC-Lavalin">SNC-Lavalin</a> was rejected by the Philippine government in 2005. The government is working with advisers (<a href="International%20Finance%20Corporation">International Finance Corporation</a>, <a href="White%20%26amp%3B%20Case">White & Case</a>, Halcrow, and others) to conduct an open-market invitation to tender for the construction of the extension and a 30-year concession to run it. An additional extension from Bacoor to <a href="Imus">Imus</a> and from there a further extension to <a href="Dasmari%C3%B1as">Dasmariñas</a>, both in Cavite, are also being considered. On March 22, 2012, the Line 1 south extension project was approved by the <a href="National%20Economic%20and%20Development%20Authority%20%28Philippines%29">National Economic and Development Authority</a> (NEDA). In line with this, the operations and maintenance of Line 1 was awarded to the <a href="Light%20Rail%20Manila%20Corporation">Light Rail Manila Corporation</a> in 2014 and started operating the line on September 12, 2015. The groundbreaking ceremony of the south extension was held on May 4, 2017, with construction beginning on May 7, 2019. Partial operations of the south extension is slated for 2024, with full operations slated by 2027.
The LRTA is also currently conducting studies on the feasibility of a , four-station Line 1 spur from Baclaran towards Terminal 3 of the <a href="Ninoy%20Aquino%20International%20Airport">Ninoy Aquino International Airport</a>, with a projected daily capacity of 40,000 passengers. Funding for the project could be sourced from either official development assistance or a <a href="public-private%20partnership">public-private partnership</a>.
Line 2 is planned to be extended westward from Recto up to the <a href="Manila%20North%20Harbor">Manila North Harbor</a> in Tondo.
New lines.
The LRT Line 6 was originally conceived as a continuation of the LRT Line 1 to <a href="Dasmari%C3%B1as">Dasmariñas</a>, <a href="Cavite">Cavite</a>. In its current form, the "Modified" Line 6 proposal is a <a href="elevated%20railway">elevated railway</a> from <a href="Niog%20station">Niog station</a> in Bacoor to Governor's Drive station in Dasmariñas via the Molino–Paliparan Road. The line will also be extended further north to <a href="Ninoy%20Aquino%20International%20Airport">Ninoy Aquino International Airport</a> (as Line 6B) in <a href="Pasay">Pasay</a> and further south as <a href="Tagaytay">Tagaytay</a> (as Line 6A extension). There will also be branch lines passing through <a href="Dr.%20Santos%20Avenue">Dr. Santos Avenue</a> and <a href="Alabang%E2%80%93Zapote%20Road">Alabang–Zapote Road</a> in southern Metro Manila.
